page.title: 16Wildlife changes near Alford
page.content: There has been a drastic decline in the butterfly population with the woodland fritillaries now completely extinct. No one is sure why, pollution and climatic changes are two factors frequently blamed. A climatic change has been evident since the 1940's with animals attracted here that were never normally seen. The collared dove is now a common bird, almost a pest. The red squirrel has gone, again no one knows why, replaced by the imported grey squirrel. The greatest single change in the landscape since the 1970's is the total removal of the Elm tree by Dutch Elm Disease. The Lincs and S.Humberside Trust have several reserves managed on the traditional lines once common. They are replanting trees and encouraging the return of plants and animals.
